titlestmt.titleproper: Casey Murrow Collection of Edward R. Murrow MaterialsMS255

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-03-09 15:13:42 -0500.

did.unittitle: Casey Murrow Collection of Edward R. Murrow Materials

physdesc.extent: 7 record cartons, 1 oversize box, 2 volume boxes

did.abstract: The Casey Murrow Collection of Edward R. Murrow Materials contain photographs, correspondence, clippings, scrapbooks, speeches, scripts, books, and legal documents dating from 1791 to 2003. The collection documents broadcast and television journalist Edward R. Murrow's personal and professional life, as well as the lives of his wife, Janet (Brewster) Murrow, and his son, Casey Murrow.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Casey Murrow, 2018, accession number MS-2019-039, 2019, accession number MS-2019-035, and 2022, accession number MS-2023-043.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged in four series: photographs and memorabilia, personal papers, professional papers, and 2022 accessions.

Series one has been arranged by format. Series two has been physically maintained in received order. Intellectually, similar materials have been grouped together, particularly where groups of photographs share a subject or location. Series three has been left in its received order, with the exception of intellectually grouping photographs of Edward R. Murrow and photographs from Murrow's time working for the U.S. Information Agency. Series four has been left in its received order.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Edward R. Murrow (1908-1965) was a prominent CBS broadcaster during the formative years of American radio and television news programs. Stationed in London for CBS Radio from 1937 to 1946, Murrow assembled a group of erudite correspondents who came to be known as the "Murrow Boys" and included one woman, Mary Marvin Breckinridge. Murrow's and their broadcasts from London, Europe, Africa, and Asia before and during World War II set the standard for US foreign news broadcasting. They also helped shape the public's view of a war that Americans were at first reluctant to be drawn into.

Returning to the US in 1946, Murrow became one of the most renowned radio and television news broadcasters of his time. Particularly famous were his programs Hear It Now, This I Believe, Person to Person, See It Now, and Years of Crisis. Of particular note are his 1954 broadcast about Senator Joseph McCarthy's persecution of presumed Communists and his 1960 Harvest of Shame documentary depicting the plight of migrant farm workers in the US. From 1961 to January 1964 he served as the Director of the United States Information Agency (USIA). Murrow died of cancer on April 27, 1965.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Charles Casey Murrow, known as Casey Murrow, was born on November 6, 1945 in London, England. He is the son of broadcasting journalists Edward R. Murrow and Janet Brewster Murrow.

In 1946, the Murrows left England for Massachusetts, where Casey Murrow attended Milton Academy, graduating in 1964. He received B.A. degrees in history and psychology from Yale University in 1968, and later earned an M.A. in education from Antioch College. In 1968, Murrow married Liza Ketchum, and they are the parents of two sons.

As of 2018, Murrow is Director of Synergy Learning, a nonprofit organization specializing in science and math programs for schools and teachers, and heads the Southeast Vermont Learning Collaborative, one of Vermont's six education service agencies.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Casey Murrow Collection of Edward R. Murrow Materials, 1791 -- 2003. Tufts University. Tufts Archival Research Center. Medford, MA.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processing of series one was completed by Leah Edelman in 2018. Materials were placed in archival boxes and loose materials were placed in folders. Received order was maintained. A box-level inventory and series-level description were created, and the finding aid was also created at the time of processing.

Series two and three were processed by Records and Accessioning Archivist, Jane Kelly, in 2020. Materials were rehoused in archival boxes. Loose materials and materials originally stored in oversize mailing envelopes were placed in archival folders, and descriptive titles were devised. Original folders that lacked meaningful descriptive information were replaced and folder titles were created for those files. The majority of folder titles were provided by the creator(s) and have been preserved. Received order has been maintained.
Series four was processed by Kate McNally, Records and Accessioning Archivst, in 2023. Materials were rehoused in archival boxes and folders. Received order has been maintained.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Janet Brewster Murrow and Edward R. Murrow Family Papers, 1920-1989. Tufts University. Tufts Archival Research Center. Medford, MA.
Edward R. Murrow Papers, 1890-1992. Tufts University. Tufts Archival Research Center. Medford, MA.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Casey Murrow Collection of Edward R. Murrow Materials contain photographs, correspondence, clippings, scrapbooks, speeches, scripts, books, and legal documents dating from 1791 to 2003. The collection documents broadcast and television journalist Edward R. Murrow's personal and professional life, as well as the lives of his wife, Janet (Brewster) Murrow, and his son, Casey Murrow.

Photographs of the Murrow family make up a significant portion of the collection, and include photos of Edward, Janet, and Casey individually and together and photographs of the extended Murrow and Brewster families. The personal papers in the collection also document the Murrow family home in Pawling, NY and of the settlement of the Murrow estate. The professional papers primarily document the work of Edward R. Murrow in London during World War II, at CBS from 1935 to 1960, and as Director of the U.S. Information Agency from 1961 to 1963. Records that date from after his death in 1965 relate to the Murrow estate, tributes and memorial events, and biographies about Murrow.
Many files in the collection include notes supplied by Casey Murrow that provide context about the subjects and individuals represented in the records, including date information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material in this collection may be protected by copyright and other rights. Please see "Reproductions and Use" on the Tufts Archival Research Center website for more information about reproductions and permission to publish. No documentation is available regarding the intellectual property rights in this collection.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Material related to the Murrow estate and biographies by Joseph E. Persico, A. M. Sperber, and Alexander Kendrick originally belonged to James M. Seward, the executor of the Murrow estate and former vice-president at CBS. This material appears to have been transferred to Janet Murrow and from her to Casey Murrow.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aids
otherfindaid.p: Information regarding the contents of many folders was provided by Casey Murrow and remains in or attached to the relevant file. These notes include information such as the individuals and locations of photographs and the approximate or known date of photographs. This information has been incorporated into the collection description but has not been fact checked.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains three Murrow family photographs; a list of Person to Person participants from Variety Magazine; a drawing referencing Edward Murrow; and a promotional poster of Edward Murrow.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This series is open for research.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Casey Murrow, 2018, accession number MS-2019-039.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This file contains three Murrow family photographs; a list of Person to Person participants from Variety Magazine; a drawing referencing Edward Murrow; and a promotional poster of Edward Murrow.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This series is open for research.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains photographs, photograph albums, scrapbooks, correspondence, clippings, and legal documents. Material dates from approximately 1890 to 2003, with the bulk of the material dating from 1940 to 1965. This material documents the family lives of Edward R. Murrow, Janet (Brewster) Murrow, and Casey Murrow. Photographs of Edward, Janet, and Casey Murrow and the extended Murrow and Brewster families make up a significant portion of the series. The Murrow family is also documented through correspondence between family members; Brewster family genealogical research; records related to the Murrow family home and Glen Arden farm in Pawling, NY; and estate records, contracts, power of attorney documents, and other legal and financial records.

Other personal items in this series include Edward R. Murrow's birth and death certificates, passport, work identification cards, high school yearbooks, and pistol permit application; Janet Murrow's address book; and World War II ration and savings books.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Casey Murrow, 2019, accession number MS-2019-035.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This series is open for research.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains photographs, clippings, correspondence, contracts and other legal documents, speeches, scripts, and proposals for biographical works on Edward R. Murrow. The material dates from 1920 to 2002, with the bulk dating from the 1930s to 1970s, several years after Edward R. Murrow's death. This series primarily documents the professional work of Edward R. Murrow in London during World War II, at CBS from 1935 to 1960, and as Director of the U.S. Information Agency from 1961 to 1963. Photographs and correspondence document his work as a broadcast and television journalist, including his highly publicized conflict with Senator Joseph McCarthy in 1954.

Janet Murrow's professional life is represented in this series through photographs and other records of her reporting work in London during World War II. Legal documents and correspondence reflect Janet Murrow's role in managing the Murrow estate after Edward R. Murrow's death in 1965. There are proposals for biographical works about Edward R. Murrow, including books, television shows, film, and plays, photographs and ephemera from events to honor Murrow, and litigation related to the use of the Murrow family name. Photographs and correspondence document Casey Murrow's presence at events in honor of Edward R. Murrow and invitations to speak about his father. Material relating to the Murrow estate and biographies on Edward R. Murrow appears to have been transferred from CBS to Janet Murrow and later to Casey Murrow.

Significant figures who are featured in the photographs in this series include U.S. Presidents Harry Truman, Dwight D. Eisenhower, John F. Kennedy, and Lyndon B. Johnson; Israeli Prime Minister David Ben-Gurion; Senator Joseph McCarthy; CBS newsmen Fred Friendly and William Paley; and other politicians and television personalities.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Casey Murrow, 2019, accession number MS-2019-035.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains a two-volume first edition of "The Life of Samuel Johnson, LL.D" by James Boswell, as well as a letter from Howard K. Smith to Edward R. Murrow upon his departure from CBS. The volumes date to 1791 and the correspondence from 1946. The volumes were gifted to Edward R. Murrow by Howard K. Smith, Murrow's successor as London Bureau Chief for CBS.
